With the support of this Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MSPRF), B. Osting was a postdoctoral fellow and instructor at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) under the mentorship of Professor S.J. Osher. The goal of this project was to use analytical and computational methods to study a variety of eigenvalue optimization problems, including the problem of finding long-lived scattering resonances of the inhomogeneous Helmholtz equation.

In the time-independent analysis of energy-conserving wave equations, scattering resonances control scattering loss, the rate at which energy escapes from a compact set to spatial infinity; the imaginary part of a resonance determines the time scale for scattering loss. Such wave equations have broad applications to the study of linear and nonlinear optics, cavity QED, Bose-Einstein condensation, quantum computation, acoustic and water waves, and other physical systems. In particular, scattering loss is often a limiting factor in the performance of engineered devices, and as such, there is both fundamental and applied interest in finding structures with low scattering loss-rate.  A natural mathematical question to pose then is: How do you design a structure (physical material properties) to minimize scattering loss. Physically this corresponds to building a device (for example, a photonic crystal) which traps a wave for the longest period of time. 

Together with M.I. Weinstein, B. Osting studied the problem of finding long-lived resonance states in the Helmholtz equation. Using variational methods, they proved the existence of a material structure (within a specified admissible set), which has an associated resonance with minimal imaginary part. Furthermore, if the refractive index is constrained to satisfy upper and lower pointwise bounds, they showed that the optimal refractive index will attain these bounds almost everywhere. Physically, this means that the structure can be built using only two materials. In one dimension, the optimal structure was shown to be asymptotically related to the Bragg structure. B. Osting also proved a related result that the Bragg structure prevents the propagation of waves with frequency within an optimally large frequency range.  

Additionally, B. Osting also studied several shape and manifold optimization problems for eigenvalues of the Laplace and Laplace-Beltrami operators. One outcome of this work was a graph partitioning method (a.k.a. data clustering) which minimizes the sum of the Laplace-Dirichlet eigenvalues for the partition components. With E. Oudet and C. White, he introduced a relaxation for this objective and a novel computational method which provably decreases the objective at each iteration and hence converges in a finite number of iterations. This method achieves state-of-the-art performance on a variety of test datasets for unsupervised machine learning and image segmentation. 

In addition to the support of the above research activities, this award allowed B. Osting to develop deeper ties to the mathematical community through increased participation in conferences, initiating new collaborations, and broad dissemination of results. The teaching option for this fellowship also facilitated B. Osting to improve his teaching and deepen his understanding of material in his research area. This award had a very positive impact on his scientific development of B. Osting and helped him to obtain a a tenure-track Assistant Professorship in Mathematics at the University of Utah.
